content:
I edited the statement to clarify the things I mentioned a year ago.

However, after getting this again in a clash I got stuck once more...

Why is the first answer [3, 0, 1] instead of [2, 2, 0]? Both get you from 2000 to 1000 in 4 jumps... There's nothing in the statement that explains why one should be preferred over the other that I can see...
4 test cases is nowhere near enough for this ‚Äì there are tons of different scenarios to cover. I just got 100% from test cases and 50% from validators.

Love to see a fellow nakama making fun puzzles. :)

I just got this in a clash though and no one could solve it more than 50-75%.
A big problem is just that you specifically say "NB: If you can't reach the exact Y date you want, take the value below it that is closest to Y."

It's unclear what "below" means here, since lower would be further back in time while higher would be a fewer jumps.

Can you clarify and reword maybe?

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle, good test cases, short to solve (~15 lines for me). Would love to get this in clash of code. üëç

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: is fun and simple, is good for clash of code fast mode as it can be solved in less than 5 min

I would like to say I really like the puzzle, its simple and fun, I think "take the value below it that is closest to Y" should be a bit more clarified, possibly with some examples.
Overall, the exercise is really good, well done!
Its a very great game! I love it

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great game ! funny and possible to do in 15min

Goal section
* Please format "inter" as a [[variable]].

* Please standardise the variable names: you have used [[inter]] in Goal section, [[ith]] in Input section, and [[year]] in stub generator.

* Suggest to add a bullet point in front of each of the rules to improve readability.

* Please insert a line break before "Your task" to separate the task from the rules.

Input section
* Please change "Next lines" to "Next [[N]] lines".

Output section
* Please change "Next lines" to "Next [[N]] lines".

* Please change "how many year" to "how many years".

* Suggest to change "ranked from the highest to the lowest" to "sorted in descending order of years per jump" for clarity.

* I don't understand what you mean by "lower solution".  There are three scenarios:
(a) The closest one I can get to is a later year. For example, the target is year 2000, I'm able to get to either 2005 or 1995 only - which year should I get to?

(b) The closest one I can get to is an earlier year. For example, the target is year 2000, I'm able to get to either 2010 or 1995 only - which year should I get to?

(c) There are two years closest to the target, one is earlier and one is later. For example, the target is year 2000, I'm able to get to either 2005 or 1995 only - which year should I get to?

"Nearest lower solution" is a bit confusing, so please reword it a bit. Also, please move the NB to Goal section after you add the clarification.

Stub generator
* Please change line 1 to parse the line into two integers X and Y (i.e. two reads) instead of one string.

Thanks.
Thanks for your precise answer! The necessary changes have been made

Oh I get it now.
'Take the year in the past that is the same year or earlier if you can't reach it exactly.'

Makes sense now. But I recommend adjusting the description, because it currently says a few misleading things like 'Each jump takes a fixed number of years in inter' which makes it sound like there's only one inter, and 'task is [,,,] in the shortest time possible' (rather than 'least jumps possible')

I've put below an edited Statement I think would help remove some of the confusion. :)

Your time machine is currently at the year [[X]], and you need to travel back in time to the year [[Y]]. However, the time warp technology is experimental and unstable, making it difficult to pinpoint precise destinations. You can only move the number of years in certain given intervals [[inter]].

Write a program that calculates the minimum number of time jumps required to reach the year [[Y]] from the year [[X]], given the following rules:

- You can perform jumps to previous years only (no traveling into the future).
- You can only jump back in time in intervals of [[inter]]
- Your task is to find the most efficient combination of jumps that will get you to the year [[Y]] in the least jumps possible.

NB: If you can't reach the exact [[Y]] date you want, take the value below it that is closest to [[Y]] (i.e. go further back in time if you can't arrive perfectly).

The problem is poorly written: some explanation is missing (hence your editing the statement and your question of why [3, 0, 1] is preferred over [2, 2, 0]?), and it does not adequately cover all cases, especially those where the author's solution is incorrect.

Why [3, 0, 1] instead of [2, 2, 0]:
The author's solution uses a greedy strategy: it tries to jump back the largest possible interval first, then the next largest, and so on. However, this approach fails for certain inputs, e.g.

2000 1000
3
200
100
390

Their output is:
2 390 1220
1 200 1020
1 100 920

However, this is incorrect. A valid solution exists that reaches exactly 1000.

The only way to justify the author's solution is by stating that it intentionally follows a greedy approach, prioritising the largest possible jumps first, even though this strategy doesn't always yield the most optimal path to the destination.

Wow... thanks for investigating.
This really shouldn't be enabled right now.

Good to know what the issues are at least, but I wish there was a way to disable it until the author can come and fix the problems. It's a shame to have a clash with such errors active.

Hope the clash gets fixed by the author or so badly rated that it gets deactivated one day.

(Now I want to travel back in time to reject it in the first place‚Ä¶)

Missed one!

Stub generator
* Please change [[year]] to [[inter]] for consistency.

New comment:

Output section
* Suggest to change "number of jumps" "how many years per jumps" "year after those jumps" to <<number of jumps>>, <<how many years per jump>> and <<year after those jumps>> to improve readability. That is, remove the quotation marks and apply the bold format.

(Note that "per jumps" should be changed to "per jump".)

Thanks again.
